Today’s House vote affirms that there is no question about what happened to the Armenian people, and that we will never forget it. We must work harder to raise awareness about this dark chapter of history out of respect for Armenians across the globe.

In order to prevent new acts of genocide, the US must be consistent in its condemnation of genocide through history.

Armenian Americans whose ancestors faced extreme atrocities a century ago deserve to know that the US fully recognizes & condemns the #ArmenianGenocide.

The higher education system in America is broken. Today, @EdLaborCmte is taking steps to fix it. The #CollegeAffordabilityAct is a comprehensive plan to cut the cost of college, improve quality and increase access to higher ed so that students can spend less and earn more.

We have lost one of the stalwarts of the civil rights struggle, John Conyers. A young congressman whom President Johnson called to get a read on the Detroit Uprising of 1967. The father of MLK Day. A person who spoke truth to power for decades.

It’s incredibly moving for me to be with Jews from all of Metro Detroit to commemorate the anniversary, or yahrzeit, of the #TreeofLife massacre. In quiet determination, in love, in openness, we will defeat anti-Semitism and white supremacy in all its forms. pic.twitter.com/jZP73rpHFb

Throughout his public service and after it ended, he was a real statesman for MI. He stood up for integrity in politics beyond partisan labels and ideology. Countless Michiganders & Americans will miss Governor Milliken deeply. I wish his family comfort in this difficult time.

Bill Milliken represents many things that are in short supply in today’s politics. He was dignified. He was thoughtful. He was a true environmentalist. He helped reduce pollution in MI & clean up our rivers, wetlands & Great Lakes in ways that have left a lasting legacy.

Amidst our weighty business - for me, deposing a key witness in the impeachment inquiry & moving forward a monumental bill to allow Medicare to negotiate prescription drug prices and bring them down to Earth - I am stopped in my tracks. Elijah Cummings, gentle giant, Godspeed.

Elijah Cummings represents everything I love and respect about this place. He was so deeply grounded in his District. He loved his constituents. He governed with a rich mix of compassion and statesmanship. I am speechless this morning.

We must channel these connections to foster respect for human rights and encourage peaceful resolution of conflicts. We must remember the resilience of these brave people who have persevered to build better lives for their children. May they inspire us to build a better world. pic.twitter.com/8mvHAdluWo

Perhaps the greatest triumph, though, is that of the human spirit. Mothers said they wished they could make food for us during our visit. When asked what brought them joy, parents said seeing their children happy. Our lives may be very different, but we share a common humanity. pic.twitter.com/xbJt3O1ZWF

Let us not forget the degradation of our planet caused by massive migrations like this. The Rohingya camps were once forested, with elephants roaming. The overwhelming deforestation is happening in a country already hugely vulnerable to and affected by climate change. pic.twitter.com/W0BThJOmE1

Let us admit our shame as Americans that this already densely populated country with mass poverty hosts a million refugees, even as we turn our back on folks at our own border. Had the Rohingya come to our shores, might their children have been ripped from their arms and caged? pic.twitter.com/uGQObmctJd

The cost to Bangladesh in hosting and administering all of these people, the infrastructure, the management – It is huge. And what of the cost to the world community? With so many needs around the globe, Burma’s actions have caused a mass investment to stabilize this population. pic.twitter.com/BRsM7uUnrW

Our #LearningTour visited 34 #Rohingya refugee camps close to Burma’s border where hundreds of thousands crossed to escape terror⁠—and where they still cannot return. My first impression is of quiet horror, a sea of suffering with little outlet for expression and accountability. pic.twitter.com/SHki4xtbxi

We met union activists and leaders at @AFLCIOGlobal Solidarity Center. I'm proud that @USAID funds this effort to help workers organize. However, it’s rough going. I was deeply moved by these brave workers and what they are doing to win a decent life in Bangladesh. pic.twitter.com/QkxkIzsFYv

Our #LearningTour visited a garment factory in Dhaka to gain an understanding of the working conditions and how @CARE equips workers to know their rights. Most of these women travel from distant villages⁠—often leaving family behind⁠—to provide a better life for their children. pic.twitter.com/FDtU2QR2Pi

I came to Congress to raise the standard of living for families, including abroad. As a member of the @HouseForeign Committee, I wanted to see how U.S. assistance provides support for the most vulnerable, so I joined the @CARE #LearningTours to Bangladesh. pic.twitter.com/oNdWQy7gO6
